content:
The manual calculation method can be a great way to get a better understanding of your travel patterns, and it's a good exercise in reflection, as you mentioned.

Wow, flying once a week for three months is indeed a lot of flying! That's a significant amount of time spent in the air, and it's impressive that you've been able to maintain that pace. You must be a seasoned traveler by now!

As you go through your trips, you might start to notice patterns, such as:

* Frequent destinations or routes
* Peak travel periods (e.g., certain days of the week or months)
* Modes of transportation used (e.g., flights, trains, cars)
* Trip durations and layovers
* Time zones crossed

These insights can help you optimize your travel routine, find ways to reduce fatigue, and even identify opportunities to accumulate loyalty points or rewards.

Remember to take breaks and stretch your legs (literally!) as you go through your travel history. It might be helpful to categorize your trips into personal and work-related travel to get a better sense of your overall travel habits.

How do you think you'll use these insights to inform your future travel plans?
